69.text: Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?

110.text: Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. You can then say the following words silently to yourself:

158.text: May there be love in my family.

236.text: The same as Ship to Shore but with Stage Directions: “Stage Right, Stage Left, Downstage, Upstage, Centre Stage.”

255.text: You can have fun actions like “Dramatic Death, Take a Bow, Open the Curtain, Clean the Floor,” etc.

274.text: Instead of “Lifeboat” you make “Cast of Actors.” Those not in the cast become the director!

293.text: This game is great if you have at least 4 people

304.text: Tell the story about a ferocious dragon who lived near a village. He would sneak into the village at night and steal people’s treasures – anything they loved.  Anybody who tried to take their treasure back would be eaten alive.  This continued for many years until the dragon became old, fat, and blind from sitting on his treasure and gazing at the glare of the gold coins. Then the townspeople could try and sneak into his lair and steal back their relatives’ treasure.

390.text: One person plays the dragon. Dragon sits blindfolded or with eyes closed surrounded by a pile of treasure.

409.text: Everyone has one piece of treasure that they must steal back.

421.text: If the dragon hears you and points at you, you must go back to the starting place.

439.text: Only one person can try to get the treasure at a time.

457.text: This game is best when more than 2 people play

467.text: One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner

484.text: Another person asks, “What are you doing?”

491.text: The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”

513.text: The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?”

533.text: The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

550.text: Children love to hear stories about your own life!

559.text: Think of a time when you were younger when something BIG happened to you

573.text: It can be an adventure, happy memory, or challenge that you experienced

585.text: Share it with your child and notice how they listen!

598.text: This activity helps children learn how to lead. It also builds trust between you and your child

615.text: Play a piece of music that is gentle and relaxed to encourage smooth and calming movement.

631.text: One person goes first and closes their eyes while the other person is the guardian angel or protector

649.text: The guardian angel must protect the person with their eyes closed from harm while gently dancing together

666.text: When the music ends, the dancer can open their eyes before switching roles

681.text: Choose a storyteller to start making up a story

690.text: Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time

700.text: Storyteller needs to fit that word in their story

718.text: Household chores aren’t fun… or are they? You can make them into a game, like this.

735.text: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!

744.text: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!

757.text: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!

766.text: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!

775.text: Jump up and down ten times.

781.text: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!

790.text: There’s a fire on the mountain! Run, run, run!

799.text: Put the shoes in the shoe rack.

807.text: At the End of the Day

813.text: At the end of each day, take a minute to think about the day.

829.text: Talk your child about one positive or fun thing they did.

840.text: Praise yourself for one thing you did well today.

849.text: Think of one thing that you are grateful for.

864.text: Keep it positive! Make sure your children get lots of praise when they are behaving well. This will make them want to behave that way more often.

913.text: We all appreciate it when the good things we do are recognised by others, especially when it is someone who is close to us.

938.text: That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.

959.text: Praise works for our children, too. When you bring more attention to positive behaviour, they are likely to do it more often. They also will feel good about themselves!

989.text: Here are 3 simple steps to get it right:

998.text: Step 1. Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

1035.text: Step 2. Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'

1063.text: Step 3. Praise with enthusiasm. Really mean it when you say it!

1075.text: Praise your children when they are behaving well! They may not show it but you’ll see them doing that good behaviour again…

1097.text: Well done for adding another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Try to find 3 things that you can praise your children for every day. You can also praise other adults in your household, too. Notice how they respond!

1135.text: Remember you can always type "Help" if you ever want more parenting tips or support. Chat to you later!

1155.text: Invest in One-on-One Time! The more time you spend with your children, the more likely they will listen to you and behave well at other times. It really works!

1184.text: Would you like to learn more about this tip?

1227.text: The first 1000 days of life are a window of opportunity for your baby. It is when their brain develops faster than any other time in their life. When you spend time with your baby, you build a healthy attachment between you both that will make them feel secure and loved.

1279.text: It is normal to struggle to think of what to do with our babies, especially when it seems they just eat, sleep, cry, poop, and repeat. It can be especially challenging when your baby is very young and not able to talk to you.

1323.text: When we have difficult relationships with our teenagers, it can be hard to find pleasure from spending time with them. Instead, we spend a lot of time disciplining them or complaining about how they are behaving.

1359.text: One-on-One Time with your children is free and fun. It makes children feel loved and secure, and shows them that they are important. It also increases their confidence and self-esteem!

1389.text: Would you like to learn more?

1610.text: Here are 6 tips to make One-on-One Time with your child a success:

1632.text: 2. Give your child your full attention

1639.text: 3. Let your child choose the activity

1651.text: 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing

1824.text: Try to spend time playing with your baby every day for at least 20 minutes where you are giving them your full attention. Choose a time when you are unlikely to be interrupted. Switch off the television and put away phones.

1865.text: 1. Spend at least five minutes with each child

1874.text: Even 5 minutes a day of quality time  makes a big difference. If you have more than one child, you can take turns or let each child choose an activity. It can be at the same time each day so your children look forward to it.

1921.text: Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.

1935.text: Skin-to-skin contact is especially important for new-borns and infants. For older toddlers, make sure you are at the same level as they are.

1958.text: 2. Give your child your full attention

1965.text: Make sure you will not be interrupted. Switch off the TV and put your phone on silent. It will show your child, they are important.

1990.note: This is an argument and it may be used to identify a corresponding quick reply

1998.text: 3. Let your baby take the lead

2005.text: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Remember that the world is brand new to your child!

2039.text: Children need to do things in their own time. Try to give them time to explore and be patient. Play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative.

2074.text: 3. Let your child choose the activity

2081.text: Ask your child what they would like to do. You can say, "I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you, what would you like to do?

2114.text: Set aside a specific time to spend One-on-One Time with your teen each day. Choose a time when you and our teen will not be interrupted and when your teen does not have something else that they want to do, like watching TV or playing with phones.

2161.text: 2. Let your teen choose the activity

2168.text: Tell your teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. Your teen might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy having this dedicated time with you!

2217.text: See what facial expressions your child is making. Notice what your child is interested in or looking at.

2236.text: Give just enough help to let it be the child’s achievement. It is okay to play alongside and copy what they are doing but try to let them keep the initiative. If your child gets frustrated, you can gently reassure your child by

2283.text: Choosing builds their self confidence. If they want to do something that isn’t OK with COVID-19 rules, then this is a chance to talk with them about this.

2311.text: Try to do something different than watching TV or playing with a tablet/phone. However, you may need to at first join your teen and watch their favourite TV programme with them. They may feel comfortable doing other activities with time.

2356.text: Try to follow your teen's lead during One-on-One Time. Accept their suggestions. Remember this is your teen's activity. Your job is to show an interest and say something nice.

2385.text: Listen to the sounds or words your child is making. You can even make the same sounds by copying your child!

2406.text: If your child cannot think of anything, you can give them a choice of a couple things that you know they like.

2433.text: Babies learn through play! Help your child explore the world through the five senses. Let your child use all of their senses when exploring the world. Sometimes when you read to your child, your child will want to put the book in their mouth. That is okay!

2485.text: Start talking to your baby from the moment they are born (even before when they are in the womb). Did you know your baby can even recognise their name at a very early age? Try saying your baby's name and notice how they respond!

2530.text: 4. Give your teen all of your attention.

2539.text: Switch off the television and put away phones. Make sure you can give all of your attention to your teen.

2559.text: 5. Show your teen you are really listening

2567.text: You can even try rephrasing back what your teen says when they speak to you. For example, when your teen says, “This math problem is really hard,” you can say, “Yeah, I see that you are finding it difficult.” It shows you are really listening to them and will make them feel supported.

2620.text: It is okay for your child to want to do many different things. Your child’s attention may wander to many different things during One-on-One Time. Anything that is happening can grab their attention: the sound of a siren, the feeling of a breeze, feelings in the body. Just keep your attention on your child.

2674.text: Look at your teen. Nodding or “I see” shows your teen you are really paying attention. Accept what they are saying without judging them.

2698.text: 5. Use words to describe what your child is doing

2708.text: Listening to your child is more important than talking to them at this time. If you do talk you should describe what your child is doing. Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening!

2753.text: Use words to describe actions, colours, shapes, numbers, sizes, textures, temperatures, tastes, sounds, and anything else that is happening. Speak with enthusiasm when describing what your child is doing.

2785.text: One-on-One Time with your child can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after playing with your child.

2813.text: One-on-One Time with your teen can be fun for you, too! You might even find that you feel less stressed after spending with your teen.

2838.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your child?

2858.text: 7. You can have quality time with your baby anytime!

2869.text: Look for ways you can connect with your baby playfully during feeding, bathing, and dressing. You can even make bedtime a fun and nurturing experience for you and your baby in a calm way.

2903.text: Do you want to go back and learn more about how to spend One-on-One Time with your teen?
